People’s Republic of China: Supporting the High-

Institutional Reforms

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 21092020133555712254 Generated Date: 09-Dec-2020 16:32:18 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) of the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) has requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to advance certain elements of its institutional reform path, as defined in the PRC’s high-quality 
growth agenda.1 The request has been made against the backdrop of the requirement for a more 
innovative, green, inclusive and sustainable development path, and the need to ensure a rapid 
recovery from adverse socioeconomic impacts of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. 
Specifically, the NDRC has requested support in two complementary areas: (i) strengthening 
government performance management and accountability for delivery of basic public services, 
and (ii) improving fair market access and competition. The TA responds to NDRC’s request and 
will be delivered through a combination of analytical work, policy recommendations, and capacity 
development activities, including workshops, seminars, and the study of relevant international 
experience in the two reform areas.    
 
2.  The  TA  is  in  line  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  operational  priority  on  strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity.2 The TA was prepared in consultation with the government 
and is based on the latest government priorities relating to institutional reform and post-COVID-
19 recovery. The TA is included in the list of projects agreed between ADB and the Government 
of the PRC on 22 January 2020.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Throughout  2020,  COVID-19  has  continued  to  spread  globally,  and  containment 
measures have greatly disrupted economic activity. As the pandemic persists, the gross domestic 
product (GDP) in developing Asia is projected to contract by 0.7% in 2020, the first such 
contraction since the early 1960s. The downturn is broad-based—three-fourths of the region's 
economies are expected to contract this year. The PRC is an important exception and is projected 
to experience positive growth. Nevertheless, the PRC’s GDP contracted by 6.8% year-on-year in 
the first quarter (Q1) of 2020, during the peak of its COVID-19 outbreak. Given the sharp 
contraction in Q1 and an economic recovery that is slower than anticipated, both domestically 
and globally, the PRC’s GDP is now expected to grow by only 1.8% in 2020, the lowest rate since 
1976.4    
 
4.  The PRC’s one-sided focus on economic growth has lifted millions of people out of poverty 
but has also come with significant negative side effects. Consequently, the PRC is seeking to 
rebalance its focus on economic growth, in particular to address inequality (geographic, income, 
and non-income); environmental degradation; and fiscal sustainability challenges, which almost 
all subnational governments in the PRC are facing. These ambitions are captured under the high-
quality growth agenda.5 The need for a rapid post-COVID-19 recovery further strengthens the 
imperative for rapid progress in rebalancing the PRC’s economy toward inclusive, sustainable, 
and green growth.  
 
1  Government of the PRC, Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 2019. China’s Progress Report on Implementation of the 2030 
Agenda for Sustainable Development (2019). Beijing; and World Bank. 2020. China Economic Update–Leaning 
Forward: COVID-19 and China’s Reform Agenda. Washington, D.C.  
2  ADB. Strategy 2030–Achieving A Prosperous, Resilient, Inclusive and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila; 
ADB.2019. Operational Priority 6: Strengthening Governance and Institutional Capacity. Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 16 November 2020. 
4  ADB. 2020. Asian Development Outlook 2020 Update: Wellness in Worrying Times. Manila. 
5  Government of the PRC, National Development and Reform Commission. 2016. 13th Five Year Plan for Economic 
and Social Development of the People’s Republic of China 2016–2020. Beijing.

2 
5.  According to the NDRC, the delivery of basic public services is currently hindered by 
several institutional factors that also constrain a rapid recovery from COVID-19: the need to (i) 
further clarify service delivery responsibilities across government tiers (central, provincial and sub-
provincial); (ii) strengthen public service delivery accountability arrangements; (iii) consistently 
monitor service delivery performance across provincial and sub-provincial governments to avoid 
assessment bias; and (iv) in line with the high-quality growth agenda and COVID-19 recovery 
process,  introduce  new  dimensions  to  the  performance management framework  related to 
inclusive, green, and environmentally sustainable development. 
 
6.  There is also a need to further strengthen market-oriented development, in particular 
through clarifying the optimal relationship between government and the market. Currently, one 
important aspect of this relationship is managed through a system centered on a “negative list for 
market  access.”6 This  system  has  evolved  over  time  but  not  succeeded  in  eliminating 
uncertainties surrounding restrictions on investment.  
 
7.  ADB has a well-established and recent track-record in both reform areas.7 Relevant 
lessons—e.g., related to efficiency improvements in the delivery of public services and the 
importance of properly disseminating knowledge gained as a result of TA implementation—have 
been used as important inputs in the design of the present TA.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: inclusive development strengthened, in line 
with the PRC high-quality growth agenda (2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development).8 The TA 
will have the following outcome: selected structural reforms for a sustainable post-COVID-19 
recovery  trajectory  improved. 9  The  key  indicator  for  this  outcome  is  a  policy  issuance 
incorporating TA recommendations on service delivery performance management and market 
access regulation that will be submitted for adoption by NDRC.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Government performance management and accountability strengthened. 
The TA will support (i) diagnostic studies to inform the establishment of effective mechanisms to 
allocate, measure, and monitor service delivery performance and accountability across all levels 
of  government;  (ii)  comparative  assessments  of  international  experiences  and  sharing  of 
international practices on intergovernmental functional and fiscal relations, and performance 
monitoring of public services; (iii) introduction of performance dimensions supporting green 
recovery and inclusive and sustainable development; and (iv) capacity development through the 
design and delivery of training courses on the implementation of the standardized public service 
monitoring system, which will be piloted in selected cities and counties.10 
 
6  A list that defines sectors to which access by market actors is restricted or prohibited. 
7  ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Enhancing Competition in Public Service 
Delivery. Manila; and ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Promoting the Decisive 
Role of the Market in Resource Allocation. Manila. 
8  Government of the PRC, Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 2019. China’s National Plan on Implementation of the 2030 
Agenda for Sustainable Development. Beijing. 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
10 Where relevant, this assessment will include findings from the regular performance audits done by the National 
Audit Office of the People’s Republic of China Announcement of the Audit Findings on Earthquake and Relief Fund 
Supplies of the Wenchuan Earthquake.

3
   
10.  Output 2: Market access and fair competition improved. The TA will support (i) an 
assessment of PRC market access rules and institutional systems informed by comparative 
international experiences, (ii) the sharing of international practices on unified national market 
access systems and management mechanisms that are of relevance to the PRC, and (iii) 
international policy dialogue through forums and seminars on the design and establishment of 
unified rules and institutional systems, for the service industry as a pilot.11 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $650,000, of which $600,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
12.  The government will provide in-kind counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other 
in-kind contributions.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. The Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional 
Cooperation Division of East Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants 
and monitor quality of their work. Arrangements for monitoring and evaluation will be agreed upon 
at the TA inception stage. Individual consultants and resource persons for workshops will be 
recruited. Disbursements will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, 
as amended from time to time).  
 
14.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.12 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Supporting the High-Quality Growth Agenda 
Post-COVID-19 through Institutional Reforms, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
